question: Which metabolic condition has phosphaturia and osteomalacia?
prompt:
Which metabolic condition has phosphaturia and osteomalacia?A)Fibrosarcoma
B)Osteosarcoma
C)Undifferentiated sarcoma
D)Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor
output0: Fibrosarcoma is a type of connective tissue cancer that can cause phosphaturia and osteomalacia. Phosphaturia is the excessive loss of phosphate in the urine, which can lead to osteomalacia, a condition characterized by softening of the bones.
output1: Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that can cause phosphaturia and osteomalacia. Phosphaturia is the excessive loss of phosphate in the urine, which can lead to osteomalacia, a condition characterized by softening of the bones.
output2: Undifferentiated sarcoma is a rare and aggressive type of cancer that can cause phosphaturia and osteomalacia.
output3: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are a type of sarcoma that can cause phosphaturia and osteomalacia. These tumors are malignant and can spread to other parts of the body.

question: In the transport of electrons through the respiratory chain:
correct_answer: The FAD-dependent dehydrogenases interact with the succinate CoQ reductase complex.
options: A)The antibiotic oligomycin inhibits the passage of electrons through complex II.
B)The final reduction of O2 is produced by the CoQ-cytochrome C reductase complex.
C)The FAD-dependent dehydrogenases interact with the succinate CoQ reductase complex.
D)Cytochromes are present in all respiratory complexes, ordered from highest to lowest redox potential.
prompt:
In the transport of electrons through the respiratory chain:A)The antibiotic oligomycin inhibits the passage of electrons through complex II.
B)The final reduction of O2 is produced by the CoQ-cytochrome C reductase complex.
C)The FAD-dependent dehydrogenases interact with the succinate CoQ reductase complex.
D)Cytochromes are present in all respiratory complexes, ordered from highest to lowest redox potential.
output0: Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits the passage of electrons through complex II of the respiratory chain, specifically the cytochrome bc1 complex. This inhibition prevents the production of ATP through the electron transport chain.
output1: The final reduction of O2 is produced by the CoQ-cytochrome C reductase complex, which is a complex of proteins that work together to transfer electrons from the electron transport chain to oxygen. This complex is the site of the final electron transfer in the respiratory chain, and it is the step that produces the most ATP.
output2: The FAD-dependent dehydrogenases are a group of enzymes that are involved in the transport of electrons through the respiratory chain. They interact with the succinate CoQ reductase complex, which is responsible for the final reduction of O2.
output3: Cytochromes are present in all respiratory complexes, from complex I to complex IV, and they are ordered from highest to lowest redox potential. The cytochromes play a crucial role in the transfer of electrons during the respiratory chain.

question: A 23-year-old man presents to the office for a circular, itchy rash over the abdomen that has been slowly getting worse for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a medical history of chronic dermatitis and chronic sinusitis for which he has prescriptions of topical hydrocortisone and fexofenadine. He smokes one-half pack of cigarettes every day. His vital signs include: blood pressure 128/76 mm Hg, heart rate 78/min, and respirations 12/min. On physical examination, the patient appears tired but oriented. Examination of the skin reveals a 2 x 2 cm round and erythematous, annular plaque on the abdomen 3 cm to the left of the umbilicus. There are no vesicles, pustules, or papules. Auscultation of the heart reveals a 1/6 systolic murmur. Breath sounds are mildly coarse at the bases. A KOH preparation from the skin scraping confirms the presence of hyphae. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
prompt:
A 23-year-old man presents to the office for a circular, itchy rash over the abdomen that has been slowly getting worse for the past 2 weeks. The patient has a medical history of chronic dermatitis and chronic sinusitis for which he has prescriptions of topical hydrocortisone and fexofenadine. He smokes one-half pack of cigarettes every day. His vital signs include: blood pressure 128/76 mm Hg, heart rate 78/min, and respirations 12/min. On physical examination, the patient appears tired but oriented. Examination of the skin reveals a 2 x 2 cm round and erythematous, annular plaque on the abdomen 3 cm to the left of the umbilicus. There are no vesicles, pustules, or papules. Auscultation of the heart reveals a 1/6 systolic murmur. Breath sounds are mildly coarse at the bases. A KOH preparation from the skin scraping confirms the presence of hyphae. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?A)Itraconazole
B)Griseofulvin
C)Topical clindamycin
D)Doxycycline
output0: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of tinea corporis, a common fungal infection of the skin. The presence of a round, erythematous, annular plaque on the abdomen, as well as the presence of hyphae on a KOH preparation, are both consistent with this diagnosis. Itraconazole is an antifungal medication that is effective against a wide range of fungal infections, including tinea corporis. It is a good choice for the next step in the management of this patient.
output1: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with a diagnosis of tinea corporis, a common skin infection caused by dermatophytes. The presence of a round and erythematous annular plaque on the abdomen, with no vesicles, pustules, or papules, is consistent with this diagnosis. The KOH preparation from the skin scraping confirming the presence of hyphae further supports this diagnosis. Griseofulvin is an antifungal medication that is effective against dermatophytes and is the next best step in the management of this patient.
output2: Topical clindamycin is the next best step in the management of this patient because the rash on the abdomen is consistent with the diagnosis of tinea corporis, a common fungal infection. Clindamycin is an antibiotic that is effective against fungal infections and is often used topically to treat tinea corporis. The patient's history of chronic dermatitis and chronic sinusitis, as well as the presence of a 1/6 systolic murmur, suggest that the patient may have a predisposition to fungal infections. Additionally, the patient's smoking habit may have contributed to the development of this infection.
output3: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of dermatophytosis. The presence of a 1/6 systolic murmur and mild coarse breath sounds suggest that the patient has a cardiac murmur, which is consistent with the diagnosis of dermatophytosis. The patient's history of smoking and the presence of a round, erythematous plaque on the abdomen also support this diagnosis. Doxycycline is the next best step in the management of this patient because it is an antibiotic that is effective against dermatophytes and other bacterial infections. Itraconazole, griseofulvin, and topical clindamycin are not effective against dermatophytes and are not the next best step in the management of this patient.

question: Injury to penis which of the following prevents extravasation of blood -
prompt:
Injury to penis which of the following prevents extravasation of blood -A)Bucks fascia
B)Fascia of camper
C)Fascia transversalis
D)None
output0: The Bucks fascia is a layer of tissue that surrounds the penis and prevents extravasation of blood in the event of injury. It acts as a barrier to prevent blood from leaking out of the penile tissue and causing further damage.
output1: The correct answer is B)Fascia of camper because it is a layer of fascia that surrounds the penis and helps to prevent extravasation of blood in the event of injury.
output2: The correct answer is C)Fascia transversalis. This type of fascia is present in the penis and serves to prevent extravasation of blood in the event of an injury.
output3: There is no injury to the penis that prevents extravasation of blood. The Buck's fascia, Fascia of Camper, and Fascia Transversalis are all layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue that surround the penis, but they do not prevent bleeding.

question: Golgi tendon organs used to detect ?
prompt:
Golgi tendon organs used to detect ?A)Dynamic
B)Static
C)Tension of muscle
D)All
output0: The Golgi tendon organs are used to detect dynamic changes in muscle length and tension. They are sensitive to the changes in length and tension of muscle fibers, and play a key role in regulating movement and maintaining posture.
output1: Golgi tendon organs are used to detect static tension in muscles. They are sensitive to changes in muscle length and are found in the muscles of the limbs, particularly in the tendons.
output2: Golgi tendon organs are specialized sensory receptors that detect the tension of muscles. They are located in the tendons, which connect muscles to bones, and are sensitive to changes in muscle length and tension.
output3: Golgi tendon organs are specialized sensory receptors that detect changes in muscle tension, dynamic movement, and static stretching. They are found in the tendons, which connect muscles to bones, and are sensitive to changes in the length and tension of the muscle.

question: Indicate which characteristic of the whiplash direction of the nystagmus is characteristic of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome:
correct_answer: Both with visual fixation and when canceling it is unidirectional.
options: A)With visual fixation and in the primary position of the gaze changes or alternates the direction spontaneously and periodically.
B)With visual fixation, it changes direction when looking to one side or the other.
C)With visual fixation and in the primary position of the gaze it is vertical downwards pure, without horizontal component.
D)Both with visual fixation and when canceling it is unidirectional.
prompt:
Indicate which characteristic of the whiplash direction of the nystagmus is characteristic of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome:A)With visual fixation and in the primary position of the gaze changes or alternates the direction spontaneously and periodically.
B)With visual fixation, it changes direction when looking to one side or the other.
C)With visual fixation and in the primary position of the gaze it is vertical downwards pure, without horizontal component.
D)Both with visual fixation and when canceling it is unidirectional.
output0: The characteristic of the whiplash direction of the nystagmus that is characteristic of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome is the spontaneous and periodic change in direction, as seen in option A. This is due to the fact that the nystagmus is a compensatory mechanism that occurs in response to a peripheral vestibular lesion, and it is not related to the presence of a horizontal component.
output1: The characteristic of the whiplash direction of the nystagmus that is characteristic of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome is that it changes direction when looking to one side or the other. This is a key feature of the condition that can help healthcare professionals differentiate it from other types of vestibular disorders.
output2: The characteristic of a vertical downward pure nystagmus is indicative of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome. This type of nystagmus is typically seen in conditions such as vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis, which affect the peripheral vestibular system and can cause vertigo, nausea, and unsteadiness.
output3: The characteristic of the whiplash direction of the nystagmus that is characteristic of an acute peripheral non-positional vestibular syndrome is the unidirectional movement of the nystagmus with visual fixation and when canceling. This indicates that the vestibular system is not functioning properly and is unable to maintain a stable position.

question: According to wein if there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption then substract ……..from the radiographic length
prompt:
According to wein if there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption then substract ……..from the radiographic lengthA)1mm
B)1.5 mm
C)2mm
D)2.5 mm
output0: If there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption, then the radiographic length should be subtracted by 1mm. This is because bone resorption is a process that occurs when the body breaks down and reabsorbs bone tissue, and it does not affect the position or shape of the tooth.
output1: If there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption, the radiographic length should be subtracted by 1.5 mm. This is because the bone resorption is a normal process that occurs as the child grows, and the 1.5 mm represents the average amount of bone resorption that occurs during this process.
output2: If there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption, then subtract 2mm from the radiographic length. This is based on the assumption that the bone resorption is occurring in the alveolar process of the jawbone, and not in the tooth itself.
output3: If there is bone resorption but no tooth resorption, it means that the bone is being reabsorbed but the tooth is still present. In this case, you would subtract 2.5 mm from the radiographic length to account for the bone resorption.

question:
An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
prompt:
An 8-week-old male presents with his mother to the pediatrician for a well visit. The patient has been breastfed since birth, and usually feeds for 30 minutes every 2-3 hours. The patient’s mother is concerned that her milk production is not keeping up with the patient’s nutritional requirements. She reports that about two weeks ago the patient began regurgitating breastmilk through his nose and mouth after some feeds. She reports that he seems mildly upset during the episodes of regurgitation but usually settles down quickly and is hungry again soon afterwards. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which seems to have reduced the frequency of the regurgitation. She denies any diarrhea, hematochezia, or family history of food allergies. Her older son had a similar problem with vomiting that resolved around 12 months of age. Four weeks ago, the patient’s height and weight were in the 40th and 34th percentiles, respectively. His height and weight are now respectively in the 37th and 36th percentiles. On physical exam, the patient is cooing in his mother’s lap and smiles reciprocally with her. He lifts his head and shoulders off the examination table when placed in the supine position. His abdomen is soft, non-tender and non-distended. Bowel sounds are normoactive.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?A)Initiate proton pump inhibitor
B)Obtain abdominal ultrasound
C)Reassurance and counseling on positioning
D)Recommend modification of mother’s diet
output0: The patient’s symptoms of regurgitation and the mother’s report of a similar problem with her older son suggest that the patient may have gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The patient’s weight and height percentiles being in the 30s and the mother’s concern about the patient’s nutritional requirements also support the diagnosis. The best next step in management would be to initiate a proton pump inhibitor to treat the GERD.
output1: The best next step in management for this 8-week-old male patient with a history of regurgitation and feeding difficulties is to obtain an abdominal ultrasound. This is because the patient's symptoms and history suggest the possibility of a gastrointestinal tract anomaly or malformation, such as a hiatal hernia or pyloric stenosis, which can cause regurgitation and feeding difficulties. An abdominal ultrasound can help to identify any anatomical abnormalities that may be contributing to the patient's symptoms.
output2: The patient’s symptoms of regurgitation are likely due to a positional issue. The patient’s mother has already tried limiting the volume of each feed, which suggests that she is aware of the issue and has taken some steps to address it. At this age, the patient is still developing his oral motor skills and may be having difficulty swallowing and coordinating feeding. Reassurance and counseling on positioning would be the best next step in management.
output3: The best next step in management for this patient would be to recommend modification of the mother’s diet. The patient’s symptoms of regurgitation and decreased weight gain are suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which is often associated with maternal dietary factors. The mother’s history of similar symptoms in her older son and her own history of lactose intolerance further support this diagnosis. Modifying the mother’s diet to reduce her exposure to potential triggers such as dairy or soy may help alleviate the patient’s symptoms.

question: A 13-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of pain, swelling, and redness in the left knee. This began a month ago and has been progressively worsening. He thinks his pain is due to playing soccer. He is frustrated that the pain does not respond to Tylenol. History is non-contributory. The vital signs are unremarkable. On examination, there is tenderness and warmth present over the knee with limitation of movement. The laboratory values show a normal white blood cell (WBC) count and elevated alkaline phosphatase. A radiograph of the knee shows mixed lytic and blastic lesions. Which of the following is the most probable cause of his complaints?
prompt:
A 13-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of pain, swelling, and redness in the left knee. This began a month ago and has been progressively worsening. He thinks his pain is due to playing soccer. He is frustrated that the pain does not respond to Tylenol. History is non-contributory. The vital signs are unremarkable. On examination, there is tenderness and warmth present over the knee with limitation of movement. The laboratory values show a normal white blood cell (WBC) count and elevated alkaline phosphatase. A radiograph of the knee shows mixed lytic and blastic lesions. Which of the following is the most probable cause of his complaints?A)Osteomyelitis
B)Osteosarcoma
C)Ewing’s sarcoma
D)Chondrosarcoma
output0: The most probable cause of the patient's complaints is osteomyelitis, which is an infection of the bone. The patient's symptoms of pain, swelling, and redness, along with the limitation of movement, are all consistent with this diagnosis. Additionally, the fact that the patient's pain does not respond to Tylenol suggests that the pain is not due to a simple inflammatory condition, but rather an infection that has penetrated the bone. The elevated alkaline phosphatase level on the laboratory values also supports this diagnosis.
output1: The most probable cause of the patient’s complaints is osteosarcoma. This is based on the history of progressively worsening pain, swelling, and redness in the knee, which are all consistent with a bone tumor. Additionally, the patient’s age (13 years old) and the fact that the pain does not respond to Tylenol are also consistent with a bone tumor. The radiograph of the knee showing mixed lytic and blastic lesions also supports this diagnosis.
output2: Ewing’s sarcoma is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s age, symptoms, and laboratory values. Ewing’s sarcoma is a rare bone cancer that typically affects children and young adults, and it often presents with pain, swelling, and limited mobility in the affected limb. The patient’s history of playing soccer and the radiograph findings of mixed lytic and blastic lesions are also consistent with this diagnosis.
output3: Chondrosarcoma is the most likely cause of the patient's complaints based on the history of pain and swelling in the knee, and the radiographic findings of mixed lytic and blastic lesions. Chondrosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that affects the cartilage cells and can cause pain, swelling, and limited mobility in the affected joint. The patient's age and the absence of systemic symptoms such as fever and night sweats also support this diagnosis.

question: A 23-year-old man complained of lower back pain and right leg had to conduct several months. Physical examination found that both strength 5 minutes, straight leg raising test (SLRT) right 20 °, left 70 °; bilateral deep tendon reflexes (DTR) normal, pain position about dominate the fifth lumbar nerve roots. The most likely diagnosis is:
prompt:
A 23-year-old man complained of lower back pain and right leg had to conduct several months. Physical examination found that both strength 5 minutes, straight leg raising test (SLRT) right 20 °, left 70 °; bilateral deep tendon reflexes (DTR) normal, pain position about dominate the fifth lumbar nerve roots. The most likely diagnosis is:A)Lumbar tumor
B)Lumbar disc herniation
C)Spondylolisthesis
D)Lumbar muscle tendinitis
output0: The patient's history of lower back pain and right leg pain, along with the physical examination findings of a positive straight leg raising test (SLRT) on the right side and a positive pain position about the fifth lumbar nerve roots, suggest a possible diagnosis of a lumbar tumor. This is the most likely diagnosis based on the symptoms and examination findings.
output1: The patient's symptoms of lower back pain and right leg weakness, along with the results of the physical examination (straight leg raising test and bilateral deep tendon reflexes), are consistent with a diagnosis of lumbar disc herniation. The pain position about dominating the fifth lumbar nerve roots also supports this diagnosis.
output2: The patient's symptoms of lower back pain and right leg weakness, along with the physical examination findings of a positive SLRT on the right side and a negative SLRT on the left side, suggest a diagnosis of spondylolisthesis. This condition occurs when a vertebra in the spine slips out of place, which can put pressure on the nerve roots and cause pain and weakness.
output3: The patient's symptoms of lower back pain and right leg weakness, along with the physical examination findings of decreased strength and pain localization, suggest a diagnosis of lumbar muscle tendinitis. The fact that the patient has been experiencing symptoms for several months also supports this diagnosis, as lumbar muscle tendinitis can be a chronic condition. The other options, lumbar tumor, lumbar disc herniation, and spondylolisthesis, are less likely diagnoses for this patient.
